title: Why do we need to put 'the' in front of musical instruments? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have read several answers here that are beside the point. The real question is why it is even legitimate to put a definite article, normally signifying one single particular specific object, in front of a categorical noun. It is because the syntax sounds highly irregular; it is not “whether it is the only way”, or “whether it is necessary”, or “under what circumstances”, or “whether it is required or not”, or “whether you have to or don’t have to“, as most answers tell us here; it is actually about a form of sentence that normally should NOT be valid in English AT ALL under ANY circumstances, as, of course, it is not valid in other Germanic languages as in Dutch and German. There is even an answer here about ingredients in a salad. Well, skipping ingredients and focusing on the final composition, does anybody in English say “I eat the salad” meaning “I eat salad”? No, the two are totally different in meaning — as “eating THE salad” means a particular salad, not just any old salad. It does seem that even “I play violins” makes much better semantic sense than “I play THE violin”. The phrase is a violation of one of the most rudimentary forms in English syntax. Then, why on earth? In my opinion, it is a literal idiomatic musicians’ jargon carried over in full from Italian and French, as in suono il violino and je joue le violon. In other words, I reckon that the particular expression is a… “romancism” :-))

If you say ‘do you play the guitar’, it means ‘do you play the guitar in general?’ If you say ‘do you play a guitar’, it doesn’t quite mean the same thing. Your choices for words in front of ‘guitar’ (etc): ‘my guitar’ (or your, or his, etc)‘this guitar’‘that guitar’‘the guitar’‘a guitar’‘some guitars’‘The guitar’ has a special meaning, which is not unique to musical instruments, but it is unique to disciplines (‘the arts’, ‘the sciences’, etc). It refers to a discipline as a whole. We say ‘do you play the flute?’, but we would never say ‘do you own the flute’ (it would be ‘this’ or ‘that’ flute). We use the in some other situations to refer to an entire class of things. Generally, though, we put some kind of article in front of any thing: car, television, play. You would never say ‘do you drive car?’, or ‘you own television?’ However, we would say ‘do you watch television?’ or ‘do you eat chocolate?’ In this context, ‘television’ is being used not as a defined thing, but an indeterminate amount. Rain, chocolate, carrots, summer, dreams, water, and so on.
